self.philbrown.javaQuery
Class Log

java.lang.Object
  self.philbrown.javaQuery.Log

public class Log
extends java.lang.Object

Contains static methods for logging and ANSI formatting.

Author:
Phil Brown

buildString

public static java.lang.String buildString(java.lang.Object... args)
Concatenates Strings together using a StringBuilder. This is faster than using the +-operator.

Parameters:
args - the Objects to append
Returns:
a concatenation of the Objects in args

format

public static java.lang.String format(java.lang.String format,
                                      java.lang.Object... args)
Handles String format for the default (US) Locale. This should be used for locale-agnostic messages to prevent locale errors, such as commas used instead of decimals.

Parameters:
format -
args -
Returns:

getNegativeString

public static java.lang.String getNegativeString(java.lang.String string)
Adds the ANSI code for the given string to appear with its colors inverted in the terminal. (i.e. the text will be set to the background color, and the background will be set to the text color)

Parameters:
string -
Returns:

getColoredString

public static java.lang.String getColoredString(java.lang.String string,
                                                java.awt.Color color)
Adds the ANSI code for the given string to appear colored in the terminal
The following colors are supported: black, red, green, yellow, blue, magenta, cyan, white

color -

The following colors are supported: black, red, green, yellow, blue, magenta, cyan, white

log

public static void log(java.lang.String format,
                       java.lang.Object... args)
This method is used by the core logging functions to nicely format output to the terminal

Parameters:
format - the text to display, using java string format arguments
args - the arguments to show in the format string.

info

public static void info(java.lang.String format,
                        java.lang.Object... args)
Logs a green message to the terminal (if ansi is enabled). Otherwise, it works identical to log(String, Object...)

Parameters:
format -
args -

formatStackTrace

public static java.lang.String formatStackTrace(java.lang.StackTraceElement element)
Formats a stack trace into a single line that provides relevant information for debugging

Parameters:
element - the element to format
Returns:
a well-formatted stack-trace line containing the class name, method name, and line number that, when clicked in the logcat, will display the line or source from where the message originated.

buildCommaSeparatedString

public static java.lang.String buildCommaSeparatedString(java.lang.Object... args)
Takes a list of Objects and calls their Object.toString() methods to get their string representation, then inserts a comma between all of them

Parameters:
args - a list of Objects to get as a comma-separated list
Returns:
a comma-separated list of the given args
